I know this is a sarcastic question but just to be clear or maybe for others reading this the ADP report numbers cited are based off of the hard numbers of the companies they ADP process payroll for. If the companies they process payroll for add a job, thats another check they process, and of course the opposite for job losses. Since the ADP numbers come from their own live data there arent revisions to the ADP report. BLS nonfarm payrolls are primarily based off of survey results from businesses. Initial headline releases are based off of early responders and are revised over time as additional responses and other data come in. Hence, revisions.
100. August was revised up so it looks like the economy is going even better than the reports are saying

replies.text: Your table is missing a key piece of data, analysts usually give 12 month price targets, so how accurate did the analysts price turn out to be 12 months later? Also some websites chart out in a graph both what the analysts average price target was, and where the stocks price went overtime. When you do this for some stocks, like T for example, it shows that analysts consistently call it pretty undervalued, and yet the stock also consistently under performs the market andor loses value. By your logic stocks like T would have been a good buy, even though history shows that you would have lost a lot of money in it. On the flipside meanwhile stocks like NFLX and TSLA would have been called dreadful and highly overvalued investments by analysts at various points, when it was actually the best time to buy those supposedly overpriced stocks.
Every single one of those is a tech company, you shouldnt have your whole portfolio in 1 sector
If youre interested in this style of analysis you might enjoy Tipranks.
Interesting. I kind of want to track this and see if it pans out.
Analysts ratings and price targets are absolutely useless information

Usually stock trading below target for a long period of time is a sign of consistent earning downward adjustment, meaning a stock is failing expectation either slower growth or negative growth QoQ. If the company is good, it will eventually go back on growth track like Chipotle and Eli Lilly or like McDonalds or Nike, it needs some serious stock picking skill and long time observing the industrial trend.
AMD is really interesting. One of the lowest percent to price target but 031 analysts rated it as even a buy.
What did you decide?

I should clarify, this isnt my whole portfolio, just some extra cash I came into. Like I said, Ive been investing for several years now so Ive got a portfolio that is more balanced than just this. This exercise is really just to find out where to put this 5k, and if I can find something better than just a broad market index Also, these are not all tech companies, I feel like less than half of them are.
Im intrigued. Tell me a little bit more about Tip Ranks. What is it? Ive never heard of it
Same
He put intel target at 38

Ill be honest its really not. I came to knowast year that NVDA was priced above 700 pre split but I was scared and only invested in QQQM. It then crossed 1000. I read about analyst ratings about ISRG. I invested a small amount after some research. It has gone 20 since then and has been solid despite tech sell off. I think analyst ratings is helpful to screen companies and not go tits up. I think what is usually lost is that they give a price range and typically most of us dont take risk into account and just invest blindly.
Its a site where they aggregate analyst price targets for a large number of stocks. They keep track of how accurate each analyst is for a specific stock so you get a sense of who you should follow.

Its called momentum, you rode a trade that everyone was on and it kept rising just like when Tesla was hit before and other stocks before they stagnate or decline. Analysts are also chasing the hype since very few had 700 upside target on Nvidia before it tripled they keep adjusting depending on the flowtrend
All analysts literally do is move their price targets as the stock goes up and down. It literally is useless information

Not true. Take a look at stock OTGLY. Its video game company CD Project. It has gone up 40 in last 3 months. Yet I researched and 8 analysts think it is a sell and 4 say it is a buy. I still invested because I follow the company and think there is a significant upside and current analyst opinions are recency bias. So I believe analyst opinions are a piece of information. If you blindly follow then you might get burned but using their opinion as a piece of information to screen stocks is valuable.
If analysts truly had a crystal ball why the hell would they give such valuable information away for free?

Agreed. There are also good and bad analysts. I often read reports even from what I consider good services and shake my head at times when its a field I know a lot about. To reiterate, Its a data point. If all the analysts predict a thing even if its wrong it will affect prices.

... They dont. Analysts get paid. And they are supposed to give honest projections. Its not some scam like you guys believe it is. They research the companies, speak to insiders and try to project where the stock price will be in 12 months. They can be spot on with revenue and earnings projections and still be way off on the stock price. Thats the stock market

No one has crystal ball. Again I find it is useful to screen stocks. To follow their arguments for prices. Regarding other question I agree that it cant be 100 right. But some of the opinions are behind paywall. But you still get to see the consensus buysellhold. Also some banks etc are publicly traded right? So they have to be atleast somewhat open about their investments and cant just make shit up. Again we need to do our own research at the end of the day.

I mean analyst is not a protected job description so there is a range, but yes real analysts are good at analyzing the businesses. That the stock market is highly regarded makes share price harder to gauge.
I just find that 90 of analysts follow momentum. Very few of them go against the crowd. Thus their opinions matter very little

For the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2024, global comparable store sales declined 7, and consolidated net revenues declined 3 to 9.1 billion, or a 3 decline on a constant currency basis. GAAP earnings per share is 0.80, down 25 over prior year. NonGAAP earnings per share is also 0.80, declining 24 on a constant currency basis. The companys results were primarily driven by softness in North Americas revenues in the quarter, specifically a 6 decline in U.S. comparable store sales, driven by a 10 decline in comparable transactions, partially offset by a 4 increase in average ticket. The accelerated investments in an expanded range of product offerings coupled with more frequent inapp promotions and integrated marketing to entice frequency across the customer base did not improve customer behaviors, specifically traffic across both Starbucks Rewards and nonSR customer segments, resulting in lowerthanexpected performance. Additionally, China comparable store sales declined 14, driven by an 8 decline in average ticket compounded by a 6 decline in comparable transactions, weighed down by intensified competition and a soft macro environment that impacted consumer spending. Despite our heightened investments, we were unable to change the trajectory of our traffic decline, resulting in pressures in both our topline and bottomline. While our efficiency efforts continued to produce according to plan, they were not enough to outpace the impact of the decline in traffic, commented Rachel Ruggeri, chief financial officer. We are developing a plan to turn around our business, but it will take time. We want to amplify our confidence in the business, and provide some certainty as we drive our turnaround. For that reason, we have increased our dividend Our fourth quarter performance makes it clear that we need to fundamentally change our strategy so we can get back to growth and thats exactly what we are doing with our Back to Starbucks plan, commented Brian Niccol, chairman and chief executive officer.

For years, I trusted traditional bankWallstreet Bankswhere I kept a considerable amount of 225,000 in their savings account. The bank often referred me as a Elite ,Highvalue , Premier Customer. Those words sparkled in my mind, evoking images of exclusivity and prestige. Yet, I received monthly interest of Four dollar 87 cents. Being in Silicon Valley and driven by curiosity of Fintech banks, I moved all my money to Fintech bank, they just called me by my Name, Initially, the simplicity without the title felt underwhelming, but the moment I saw the first interest paymenta staggering of 1,000 per month a meaningful returns. From Four dollar 87 cents a month from traditional bank to 1000 a month from Fintech bank, realized how traditional banks eat our money by throwing a prestigious title on US... Sometimes, it takes a little time to see the truth beneath the surface

The key to buying options is understanding how fast money can disappear with time decay. If youre buying calls. The price must move up faster than what the momentum of the stock was when you bought it. The opposite is true for puts. Almost always avoid buying any options within the first hour or two. Unless its a rare circumstance like Tesla was opening morning after earnings. Options value time decay increases rapidly the closer you get to the date of expiration. My advice to you would be to buy calls a month to three months out the day before earnings, so even if its not great, theres still time for it to recover.

The biggest argument is a high yield savings account HYSA will out pace it in a year. I think thats a bit short sighted because their acting like interest rates will never move lower, but their point still stands, currently you would be better off letting it sit and accumulate interest than bag holding. We dont even have to guess at a timeframe or anything. Just take what you would put in intel and calculate your balance in a high yield savings account over the next 2 years by month. That is literally what you are aiming to beat minimum, otherwise its actually a loss for your risk and effort. If in the next 30 days you sell for a 10 pop, great, but the company literally told everyone expect nothing for a year, and even after that, who boy, just know we are working hard and will update then. The longer you hold, the higher that needs to be just to beat the HYSA. Back to the short sightedness of the HYSA . 1 they probably are not doing that, its just a floor they are using to compare what they are doing with their money ex not giving two craps about a 1 dividend and trying to beat it. Their being smart and not marrying the play, stock or HYSA, and we all should be doing that. If the HYSA is no good, dump it and move to the next channel thats best at that time. The difference between intel and HYSA is you can get out of the HYSA at anytime with 0 loss and invest elsewhere, while Intel may have lost value. They 100 dont make perfect plays, but its hard for them to watch others make dumb plays that cant even track interest rates without saying anything. Bottom line, if you plan to be 100 passive, your picks are probably not best, especially if you refuse to pivot when terrible news shows up at the front page of every search engine. Thats why they keep screaming toss it in a fund to people who are doing this.

Dont do options. If you dont understand options you can lose a lot of money. If you do understand options you can lose an everloving shitton of money. If you watch this sub a week or two youll see guys posting 50k, 100k, 500k losses. Options were originally intended as a way to hedge your positions, and most hedge funds and serious investors still use them for that purpose. It works something like this Say i bought 10000 shares of nvda a couple years ago. Its gone up huge, lets say i paid 10 a share and theyre worth 100 a share now. I could buy long dated like years puts betting on it going to 50 or less. The puts would be very cheap for me to buy because thats very unlikely to happen but now in case something terrible does happen and nvda does crash my puts will pay off and i wont lose everything. Basically like insurance for stock positions, if that makes any sense.

Some people actually do research and make educated guesses but yea, people in this sub are mostly just gambling. Dont do options to gamble like this. This is not what they were originally intended for.

Some of that money comes in the form of monthly inflows from all the 401Ks out there. Even when the shit hits the proverbial fan like in 2020, people still leave their 401K alone. So every couple of weeks all these passive investors are autobuying lowfee index funds from their paychecks no matter if the market is up or down. Thats why the two biggest shareholders of Apple are Invesco QQQ and Vanguard. That ultimately puts a positive pressure on price, with more weight to the largest companies due to the composition of the ETFs.
